update.description:
depends on [ign-rendering pull request #256](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-rendering/pull-requests/256/support-setting-skeleton-node-weights/diff)

Integrates skeleton animation feature introduced [this ign-rendering pull request](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-rendering/pull-requests/235) that lets the render engine do the animation as opposed to manually animating the skeleton bone poses.

The manual update mode still works and can be controlled by changing the `actorManualSkeletonUpdate` bool variable in `RenderUtil.cc`. We could use a component for setting this behavior in the future.

The integration is more involved than I had hoped. Most of the logic is for syncing skeleton animation with trajectory animation. Unfortunately I still had to manually calculate the root bone pose every iteration in order to sync the two. It involves computing the correct point in time the skeleton animation is to be played when interpolate\_x is on.
update.title: Actor skeleton animation (auto update mode)

The manual update mode still works and can be controlled by changing the `actorManualSkeletonUpdate` bool variable in `RenderUtil.cc`. We could use a component for setting this behavior in the future.

The integration is more involved than I had hoped. Most of the logic is for syncing skeleton animation with trajectory animation. Unfortunately I still had to manually calculate the root bone pose every iteration in order to sync the two. It involves computing the correct point in time the skeleton animation is to be played when interpolate\_x is on.
update.title: Actor skeleton animation (auto update mode)

content.raw:
Thanks, my computer was fine with that.

I also tried adding a camera to the world and subscribe to images, and I was able to run it faster than real time with `-z 10000000`. But in this case, my mouse started lagging a bit. So it's probably close to my computer's limit.
content.html:
Thanks, my computer was fine with that.

I also tried adding a camera to the world and subscribe to images, and I was able to run it faster than real time with -z 10000000. But in this case, my mouse started lagging a bit. So it's probably close to my computer's limit.

The manual update mode still works and can be controlled by changing the `actorManualSkeletonUpdate` bool variable in `RenderUtil.cc`. We could use a component for setting this behavior in the future.

The integration is more involved than I had hoped. Most of the logic is for syncing skeleton animation with trajectory animation. content.raw: it could be memory issue? I’ll reduce the number of actors in the `actor_crowd.sdf`. There are plans to work on skeleton instancing, which should reduce resource usage.
content.html: it could be memory issue? I’ll reduce the number of actors in the actor_crowd.sdf. There are plans to work on skeleton instancing, which should reduce resource usage.

content.raw:
So... I tried `actor_crowd.sdf` and it was indeed running at 100% RTF... until... it froze my computer :slight_smile: I also noticed that it doesn't have any rendering sensors, so I think it's expected that it doesn't impact RTF.

Even with the freeze, I agree that this is an improvement though.
content.html:
So... I tried actor_crowd.sdf and it was indeed running at 100% RTF... until... it froze my computer I also noticed that it doesn't have any rendering sensors, so I think it's expected that it doesn't impact RTF.

Even with the freeze, I agree that this is an improvement though.

content.raw:
the longer load time is mainly from loading the animations into the render engine. One of the actors have 8 animations so the load time is more noticeable.

I’ll keep the trajectory stuff in there for now. We can update it later.

I added `actor_crowd.sdf` for performance testing and fixed an issue with loading duplicate animations in [6d375c7](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/commits/6d375c7929585fa023ea643db16cbd5320c43dce) . The RTF is still 100% for me in both modes as that comes from the server.  The screenshot below shows profiling using remotery:  manual update \(top\) and auto update \(bottom\). There is slight performance improvement in `RenderUtil::Update Poses` when making the ign-rendering calls to animate actors. But the real saving is implicitly captured by `RenderUtil::Update` that went down from ~32.635 ms to 2.366 ms. In manual mode, it was constantly blocked on a mutex waiting for the skeleton local transforms to be computed, confirmed by manually profiling the [Each](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/src/b23ca11d8c419d4e9f63736b4b09f76dcfba5bfb/src/rendering/RenderUtil.cc#lines-1009) function that computes these transforms which shows that it takes 2x ms.

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/1391461063-actor_manual_auto.png)
‌
content.html:
the longer load time is mainly from loading the animations into the render engine. One of the actors have 8 animations so the load time is more noticeable.

I’ll keep the trajectory stuff in there for now. We can update it later.

I added actor_crowd.sdf for performance testing and fixed an issue with loading duplicate animations in 6d375c7 . The RTF is still 100% for me in both modes as that comes from the server. The screenshot below shows profiling using remotery: manual update (top) and auto update (bottom). There is slight performance improvement in RenderUtil::Update Poses when making the ign-rendering calls to animate actors. But the real saving is implicitly captured by RenderUtil::Update that went down from ~32.635 ms to 2.366 ms. In manual mode, it was constantly blocked on a mutex waiting for the skeleton local transforms to be computed, confirmed by manually profiling the Each function that computes these transforms which shows that it takes 2x ms.

‌

content.raw:
This works for me. The only thing I noticed is that the load time seems to be longer? I consistently get a black screen for a few seconds before the scene shows.

@{557058:10b01d41-a2e9-4a41-a907-e6e2f03b6cd5} , I'll leave it up to you if you want to remove the trajectory stuff.

The only other thing I'd suggest would be an example world with a lot of actors, to show that performance should be better now.
content.html:
This works for me. The only thing I noticed is that the load time seems to be longer? I consistently get a black screen for a few seconds before the scene shows.

@Ian Chen , I'll leave it up to you if you want to remove the trajectory stuff.

The only other thing I'd suggest would be an example world with a lot of actors, to show that performance should be better now.

content.raw: Thanks for the explanation. I guess the best is to remove the warning then?
content.html: Thanks for the explanation. I guess the best is to remove the warning then?

content.raw:
looks like the loading the skin mesh also loads the animation: 

[#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/src/180e87c97955a8c1a2cfdf4872ce65c704a79e69/src/rendering/SceneManager.cc#lines-527](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/src/180e87c97955a8c1a2cfdf4872ce65c704a79e69/src/rendering/SceneManager.cc#lines-527)

We would need to explicitly remove the animation if we don’t want it to be in the mesh object. 

From the ign-rendering perspective, it does not know about this common case of actors though, it just loads whatever is contained in `common::Mesh`
content.html:
looks like the loading the skin mesh also loads the animation:

#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/src/180e87c97955a8c1a2cfdf4872ce65c704a79e69/src/rendering/SceneManager.cc#lines-527

We would need to explicitly remove the animation if we don’t want it to be in the mesh object.

From the ign-rendering perspective, it does not know about this common case of actors though, it just loads whatever is contained in common::Mesh

content.raw:
Gotcha. I think the most common case is to use the same file for both skin and animation, so it's probably best to remove the warning.

Although I thought we were purposely ignoring the animations from the file within `<skin>`?
content.html:
Gotcha. I think the most common case is to use the same file for both skin and animation, so it's probably best to remove the warning.

Although I thought we were purposely ignoring the animations from the file within <skin>?

content.raw:
the errors should be fixed. [180e87c](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/commits/180e87c97955a8c1a2cfdf4872ce65c704a79e69)

the warnings happens because one of the `<animation>`s is the same of as the animation that comes with `<skin>` mesh so in the end we pass two animations with the same name to ign-rendering. So they are expected. I can change that to `ignmsg` or remove the msg if that’s confusing to the user.
content.html:
the errors should be fixed. 180e87c

the warnings happens because one of the <animation>s is the same of as the animation that comes with <skin> mesh so in the end we pass two animations with the same name to ign-rendering. So they are expected. I can change that to ignmsg or remove the msg if that’s confusing to the user.

content.raw: currently they should not be null but I added warnings to capture the case where in the future we let users set animation properties and they specify invalid entity ids. [6c33b04](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/commits/6c33b049dc58475ae5887ff8081f464a8948d671)
content.html: currently they should not be null but I added warnings to capture the case where in the future we let users set animation properties and they specify invalid entity ids. 6c33b04

update.description:
depends on [ign-rendering pull request #256](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-rendering/pull-requests/256/support-setting-skeleton-node-weights/diff)

Integrates skeleton animation feature introduced [this ign-rendering pull request](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-rendering/pull-requests/235) that lets the render engine do the animation as opposed to manually animating the skeleton bone poses.

The manual update mode still works and can be controlled by changing the `actorManualSkeletonUpdate` bool variable in `RenderUtil.cc`. We could use a component for setting this behavior in the future.

The integration is more involved than I had hoped. Most of the logic is for syncing skeleton animation with trajectory animation. Unfortunately I still had to manually calculate the root bone pose every iteration in order to sync the two. It involves computing the correct point in time the skeleton animation is to be played when interpolate\_x is on.
update.title: Actor skeleton animation (auto update mode)

update.description:
depends on [ign-rendering pull request #256](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-rendering/pull-requests/256/support-setting-skeleton-node-weights/diff)

Integrates skeleton animation feature introduced [this ign-rendering pull request](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-rendering/pull-requests/235) that lets the render engine do the animation as opposed to manually animating the skeleton bone poses.

The manual update mode still works and can be controlled by changing the `actorManualSkeletonUpdate` bool variable in `RenderUtil.cc`. We could use a component for setting this behavior in the future.

The integration is more involved than I had hoped. Most of the logic is for syncing skeleton animation with trajectory animation. Unfortunately I still had to manually calculate the root bone pose every iteration in order to sync the two. It involves computing the correct point in time the skeleton animation is to be played when interpolate\_x is on.
update.title: Actor skeleton animation (auto update mode)
